animalOfTheDay.name: sardine
facts: Sardines get their name from the Italian island of Sardinia where they were once abundant.
They are an important food source for many marine predators, including whales and dolphins.
Sardines swim in massive schools that can contain millions of fish.
They are rich in omega-3 fatty acids and are an important commercial fish.

calendar.name: rook
facts: Rooks are highly social corvids that nest in large colonies called rookeries.
They are among the most intelligent birds and can use simple tools.
Rooks have pale, featherless faces that distinguish them from other crows.
They form lifelong pair bonds and often stay with the same mate for life.

calendar.name: rottweiler
facts: Rottweilers are descended from Roman war dogs and were used to herd cattle.
They are powerfully built dogs with a natural guarding instinct.
Despite their tough appearance, they are affectionate with their families.
Rottweilers were one of the first police dogs and are still used in K-9 units today.

calendar.name: sable
facts: They are solitary animals with large territories that they mark with scent.
Sables are small, agile members of the weasel family with luxurious fur.
Sables were once nearly hunted to extinction for their valuable fur.
They are excellent climbers and swimmers, hunting both in trees and water.

calendar.name: salmon
facts: Salmon are anadromous, meaning they migrate from saltwater to freshwater to spawn.
They use Earth's magnetic field and smell to navigate back to their birthplace.
Salmon are a keystone species, providing nutrients to forests when their carcasses decompose.
After spawning, most Pacific salmon die, while some Atlantic salmon may survive to spawn again.

calendar.name: sand dollar
facts: Sand dollars are flat sea urchins that live on the ocean floor.
When alive, they are covered in tiny, velvety spines that help them move and feed.
The five-petal pattern seen on dead sand dollars is actually their skeletal structure.
They feed by filtering tiny particles of food from the sand using their tube feet.

calendar.name: sandpiper
facts: Sandpipers have specialized bills that can sense vibrations of prey underground.
They perform elaborate aerial displays during courtship.
Some species undertake incredible migrations, flying nonstop for days over open ocean.
Sandpipers are shorebirds with long bills for probing sand and mud for food.

calendar.name: sardine
facts: They are an important food source for many marine predators, including whales and dolphins.
Sardines swim in massive schools that can contain millions of fish.
Sardines get their name from the Italian island of Sardinia where they were once abundant.
They are rich in omega-3 fatty acids and are an important commercial fish.

randomAnimals.name: badger
facts: Honey badgers are considered one of the most fearless animals in the world.
They have incredibly thick skin that can resist bee stings and snake bites.
Badgers are excellent diggers and can excavate tunnels faster than humans with shovels.
They have a symbiotic relationship with honeyguide birds in Africa.

randomAnimals.name: komodo dragon
facts: Komodo dragons are the largest living lizards, growing up to 10 feet long.
They have venomous saliva that prevents blood clotting, weakening prey over time.
Komodo dragons can eat up to 80% of their body weight in one meal.
They are excellent swimmers and can travel between islands in their native Indonesia.

randomAnimals.name: tarsier
facts: They can rotate their heads nearly 180 degrees in each direction.
Tarsiers are the only entirely carnivorous primates, eating insects, lizards, and small birds.
Tarsiers have the largest eyes relative to body size of any mammal.
They communicate using ultrasonic frequencies beyond human hearing.
